questionTitle: A train running at the speed of 60 km/hr crosses a pole in 9 seconds. What is the length of the train?

If a car travels at a speed of 60 km/hr, how long will it take to cover a distance of 150 kilometers?
What is the value of 'x' in the equation 3x + 5 = 17?

If 6x - 3 = 15, what is the value of x?

If 4x - 7 = 5, what is the value of x?

If 7x + 5 = 26, what is the value of x?

If x = 2/3, what is the value of 3x - 1?

Find the average of first 20 odd natural numbers.
If 5x - 3 = 12, what is the value of x?
What is the sum of first 30 natural numbers?

Which operator is used for incrementing the value of a variable by 1 in C++?
What does the 'cout' object in C++ do?
options: It reads input from the console
It writes output to the console
answer: It writes output to the console

questionTitle: Which data type is used to store whole numbers in C++?
What does the 'cin' object in C++ do?
options: It reads input from the console
It writes output to the console
answer: It reads input from the console

questionTitle: What is the purpose of the 'new' operator in C++?
options: It is used to delete objects
It is used to allocate memory for a new object
It is used to declare a new variable
It is used to define a new function
answer: It is used to allocate memory for a new object

questionTitle: What does the 'static' keyword indicate in C++?
options: It indicates that a variable is constant
It indicates that a variable is shared among all instances of a class
It indicates that a variable is only accessible within a specific function
It indicates that a variable is dynamically allocated
answer: It indicates that a variable is shared among all instances of a class

questionTitle: What does the 'virtual' keyword indicate in C++?
options: It indicates that a function is static
It indicates that a function is a member of a class
It indicates that a function can be overridden in a derived class
It indicates that a function is pure virtual
answer: It indicates that a function can be overridden in a derived class

questionTitle: What is the purpose of the 'this' pointer in C++?
options: It points to the previous element in a linked list
It points to the current instance of a class
It points to the next element in a linked list
It points to the base class
answer: It points to the current instance of a class

questionTitle: What does the 'const' keyword indicate in C++?
options: It indicates that a variable cannot be modified
It indicates that a variable is initialized with a specific value
It indicates that a variable is a constant
It indicates that a variable is dynamically allocated
answer: It indicates that a variable cannot be modified

options: Adds a new line and flushes the output buffer
answer: Adds a new line and flushes the output buffer

questionTitle: Which keyword is used to define a constant in C++?
What does the 'static' keyword do in C++?
options: Specifies that a variable or function is shared among all instances of a class
Specifies that a variable or function belongs to a specific instance of a class
Specifies that a variable or function cannot be modified
Specifies that a variable or function cannot be accessed from outside its class
answer: Specifies that a variable or function is shared among all instances of a class

questionTitle: What does the 'new' operator do in C++?
options: Allocates memory on the heap and returns a pointer to it
Allocates memory on the stack and returns a pointer to it
answer: Allocates memory on the heap and returns a pointer to it

questionTitle: What is the purpose of the 'virtual' keyword in C++?
options: To specify that a function should be overridden in a derived class
To specify that a function cannot be overridden in a derived class
To specify that a function should be private
To specify that a function should be static
answer: To specify that a function should be overridden in a derived class

What is the purpose of the 'extern' keyword in C++?
options: To specify that a variable is available outside the current scope
To specify that a function is implemented in another file
answer: To specify that a variable is available outside the current scope

What is the purpose of the 'this' pointer in C++?
options: To refer to the current class instance
To refer to the previous class instance
To refer to the next class instance
To refer to the main class instance
answer: To refer to the current class instance

questionTitle: What does the 'static' keyword do when applied to a class member in C++?
options: Specifies that the member is shared among all instances of the class
Specifies that the member belongs to a specific instance of the class
Specifies that the member cannot be modified
Specifies that the member cannot be accessed from outside its class
answer: Specifies that the member is shared among all instances of the class

questionTitle: What is the purpose of the 'typeid' operator in C++?
options: To identify the type of an object at runtime
To identify the type of an object at compile time
To identify the type of a class
To identify the type of a variable
answer: To identify the type of an object at runtime

questionTitle: What is the output of the following C++ code snippet?<linebreak><linebreak>```cpp<linebreak>#include <iostream><linebreak>using namespace std;<linebreak>int main() {<linebreak>  int x = 5;<linebreak>  int* ptr = &x;<linebreak>  cout << *ptr;<linebreak>  return 0;<linebreak>}<linebreak>```
What does CSS stand for?
Which CSS property is used to change the text color of an element?
What does the 'padding' property in CSS define?
options: The space between the border and the content of an element
The space between the border and the margin of an element
The space between lines of text
answer: The space between the border and the content of an element

questionTitle: Which CSS property is used to set the background color of an element?
What does the 'margin' property in CSS define?
options: The space between the border and the content of an element
The space between the border and the margin of an element
The space between lines of text
answer: The space between the border and the margin of an element

questionTitle: What is the purpose of the 'float' property in CSS?
options: To move an element to the left or right
To change the font of an element
answer: To move an element to the left or right

questionTitle: Which CSS property is used to add shadows to elements?
What does the 'display: flex;' property do in CSS?
options: It displays an element as a block-level flex container
It displays an element as an inline-level flex container
It displays an element as an inline-level block container
answer: It displays an element as a block-level flex container

questionTitle: What does the 'position: absolute;' property do in CSS?
options: Positions an element relative to its normal position
Positions an element absolutely to the browser window
Positions an element relatively to its parent element
Positions an element relatively to the viewport
answer: Positions an element absolutely to the browser window

questionTitle: What does the 'z-index' property in CSS define?
options: The order of elements along the z-axis
The order of elements along the x-axis
The order of elements along the y-axis
The order of elements within a flex container
answer: The order of elements along the z-axis

questionTitle: What is the purpose of the 'overflow' property in CSS?
options: To specify whether the content of an element should be clipped, visible, or scrollable
To control the visibility of an element
To add shadows to an element
answer: To specify whether the content of an element should be clipped, visible, or scrollable

questionTitle: Which CSS property is used to create rounded corners on elements?
What is the purpose of the 'transform' property in CSS?
options: To change the size of an element
To rotate, scale, skew, or translate an element
To change the color of an element
To change the font of an element
answer: To rotate, scale, skew, or translate an element

questionTitle: What does the 'transition' property in CSS do?
options: It specifies the timing function for a transition effect
It specifies the duration of a transition effect
It specifies the property to transition
It specifies the initial value of a property
answer: It specifies the timing function for a transition effect

questionTitle: Which CSS property is used to change the font size of an element?
What does the 'background-image' property in CSS do?
options: It specifies the color of the background
It specifies an image as the background of an element
It specifies the size of the background
It specifies the position of the background
answer: It specifies an image as the background of an element

questionTitle: Which CSS property is used to set the font family of an element?
What does the 'border' property in CSS define?
options: The space between the border and the content of an element
The color, width, and style of the border of an element
The space between the border and the margin of an element
answer: The color, width, and style of the border of an element

questionTitle: What does the 'text-align' property in CSS do?
options: It specifies the alignment of the text within an element
It specifies the size of the text
It specifies the color of the text
It specifies the font of the text
answer: It specifies the alignment of the text within an element

questionTitle: Which CSS property is used to add space between letters in a text?
What does the 'list-style-type' property in CSS define?
options: The style of the list item marker
The font of the list item text
The alignment of the list item text
answer: The style of the list item marker

questionTitle: Which CSS property is used to change the style of a list item marker?
What does the 'text-decoration' property in CSS do?
options: It specifies the color of the text
It specifies whether a line should be drawn under, over, or through the text
It specifies the font of the text
It specifies the size of the text
answer: It specifies whether a line should be drawn under, over, or through the text

questionTitle: What does the 'opacity' property in CSS do?
options: It specifies the transparency of an element
It specifies the color of an element
It specifies the size of an element
It specifies the position of an element
answer: It specifies the transparency of an element

questionTitle: Which CSS property is used to specify the distance between the text of a text element and its border?

options: It displays an element as an inline element
It displays an element as a block element

The spacing between lines of text

options: Java is a low-level programming language.
Java code is compiled into machine code.
Java is an object-oriented programming language.
answer: Java is an object-oriented programming language.

questionTitle: What is the Java virtual machine (JVM)?
options: A physical machine used to run Java code
An abstract machine that provides the runtime environment for Java bytecode
A tool used for debugging Java code
A software development kit for Java
answer: An abstract machine that provides the runtime environment for Java bytecode

questionTitle: Which of the following data types in Java is used to store single characters?
What is the purpose of the 'static' keyword in Java?
options: To specify that a variable or method belongs to the class, rather than instances of the class
To declare a method that can be overridden
answer: To specify that a variable or method belongs to the class, rather than instances of the class

questionTitle: What is the default value of a boolean variable in Java?

It indicates that a method is private
It indicates that a method is static

answer: It indicates that a method returns no value

questionTitle: Which of the following is NOT a Java keyword?
What is the difference between '==' and '.equals()' in Java?
options: '==' is used to compare primitive data types, while '.equals()' is used to compare objects.
'==' is used to compare objects, while '.equals()' is used to compare primitive data types.
'==' and '.equals()' are used interchangeably in Java.
'==' and '.equals()' are both used to compare objects in Java.
answer: '==' is used to compare primitive data types, while '.equals()' is used to compare objects.

questionTitle: What is method overloading in Java?
options: Method overloading allows multiple methods with the same name but different parameters in a class.
Method overloading allows a method to have multiple return types.
Method overloading allows a method to be overridden by a subclass.
Method overloading allows a method to have multiple access modifiers.
answer: Method overloading allows multiple methods with the same name but different parameters in a class.

questionTitle: What is method overriding in Java?
options: Method overriding allows multiple methods with the same name but different parameters in a class.
Method overriding allows a method to have multiple return types.
Method overriding allows a subclass to provide a specific implementation of a method that is already defined in its superclass.
Method overriding allows a method to have multiple access modifiers.
answer: Method overriding allows a subclass to provide a specific implementation of a method that is already defined in its superclass.

questionTitle: What is the purpose of the 'super' keyword in Java?
options: To call the constructor of the superclass
To access the superclass's methods and fields
To create an instance of a class
answer: To access the superclass's methods and fields

questionTitle: What is the purpose of the 'this' keyword in Java?
options: To call the constructor of the current class
To access the superclass's methods and fields
To refer to the current instance of the class
answer: To refer to the current instance of the class

options: Iterates over an array and returns a new array with modified elements
Iterates over an array and returns the first matching element
Iterates over an object and returns a new object with modified properties
Iterates over an object and returns the first matching property
answer: Iterates over an array and returns a new array with modified elements

questionTitle: What does the 'isNaN' function in JavaScript do?
options: Checks if a value is not a number
Checks if a value is a number
Converts a value to a number
Returns the index of the first occurrence of a specified value
answer: Checks if a value is not a number

questionTitle: Which keyword is used to define a function in JavaScript?

What is the purpose of the 'forEach' method in JavaScript?
options: Iterates over an array and returns a new array with modified elements
Iterates over an array and returns the first matching element
Executes a provided function once for each array element
Creates a new array with all elements that pass a test
answer: Executes a provided function once for each array element

questionTitle: What will be the output of the following code?<linebreak><linebreak>```javascript<linebreak>var x = 10;<linebreak>function foo() {<linebreak>  console.log(x);<linebreak>  var x = 20;<linebreak>}<linebreak>foo();<linebreak>```
What is the purpose of the 'filter' method in JavaScript?
options: Iterates over an array and returns a new array with modified elements
Iterates over an array and returns the first matching element
Executes a provided function once for each array element
Creates a new array with all elements that pass a test
answer: Creates a new array with all elements that pass a test

questionTitle: What does the 'reduce' method do in JavaScript?
options: Iterates over an array and returns a new array with modified elements
Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in the array to reduce it to a single value
Executes a provided function once for each array element
Creates a new array with all elements that pass a test
answer: Applies a function against an accumulator and each element in the array to reduce it to a single value

questionTitle: What is the output of the following code?<linebreak><linebreak>```javascript<linebreak>console.log(3 * '2');<linebreak>```
What is the purpose of the 'apply' method in JavaScript?
options: Executes a function once for each array element
Creates a new array with all elements that pass a test
Invokes a function with a given 'this' value and arguments provided as an array
Binds a function to a particular object, meaning that function will always have a particular 'this' value
answer: Invokes a function with a given 'this' value and arguments provided as an array

questionTitle: What will be the output of the following code?<linebreak><linebreak>```javascript<linebreak>function outer() {<linebreak>  var x = 10;<linebreak>  function inner() {<linebreak>    console.log(x);<linebreak>  }<linebreak>  return inner;<linebreak>}<linebreak>var closureFunction = outer();<linebreak>closureFunction();<linebreak>```
What does the 'bind' method do in JavaScript?
options: Creates a new array with the results of calling a provided function on every element in the array
Binds a function to a particular object, meaning that function will always have a particular 'this' value
Executes a provided function once for each array element
Creates a new array with all elements that pass a test
answer: Binds a function to a particular object, meaning that function will always have a particular 'this' value

questionTitle: What is the purpose of the 'try...catch' statement in JavaScript?
options: Declares a block of code, variables, or functions that can be executed later
Handles runtime errors by catching exceptions
Performs a conditional test and executes a statement if the test passes
answer: Handles runtime errors by catching exceptions
